key_risks: Regulatory and compliance issues, including a $10 million SEC settlement for internal control failures
Cybersecurity vulnerabilities, including ransomware attacks and data breaches
Customer service and claims processing issues, leading to above-average complaints
Low interest rate environment impacting investment returns and annuity pricing
Pension risk transfer liabilities posing long-term financial risks
controversies: $10 million SEC settlement for accounting errors in annuities businesses
RansomHub ransomware attack claims and MOVEit breach allegations
Persistent customer complaints about car insurance claims processing
social_issues: Customer dissatisfaction with claims processing and service quality
governance_issues: Internal control failures and accounting errors leading to regulatory penalties
Ongoing regulatory scrutiny across multiple jurisdictions

sources.title: Internal Control Failures Cost MetLife $10 million in SEC Settlement
sources.snippet: MetLife, Inc. has agreed to pay a civil penalty of $10 million in order to settle charges from the Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC") that it violated the books and records and internal accounting controls provisions of the federal securities laws. Read the full SEC Press Release Here. MetLife's Retirement and Income Solutions Error

sources.title: MetLife to Pay $10 Million for Longstanding Internal Control Failures
sources.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged MetLife, Inc. with violating the books and records and internal accounting controls provisions of the federal securities laws relating to two errors in its accounting for reserves associated with its annuities businesses. MetLife has agreed to pay $10 million to settle the charges.

sources.title: US regulators label MetLife as potential financial threat
sources.snippet: WASHINGTON (AP) — U.S. regulators have labeled insurer MetLife as a potential threat to the financial system, a designation that brings stricter government oversight. MetLife said Thursday that the Financial Stability Oversight Council has designated the company as "systemically important." As a result, MetLife must increase its cushion of capital against losses, limit its use of borrowed ...
